TimeWeaver Class

The TimeWeaver class facilitates data preprocessing, analysis, and evaluation of interpolation methods on pandas DataFrames, especially for time-series data.

Class Documentation

class timeweaver.TimeWeaver(df: DataFrame, tracking_column: str)

Bases: object

Facilitates data preprocessing, analysis, and evaluation of interpolation methods on pandas DataFrames, particularly for time-series data. It summarizes data characteristics, preprocesses data, and evaluates various interpolation methods under different conditions.

Parameters

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame to analyze and process.

  • tracking_column (str) – The column name used for tracking, often representing time.

Attributes: - df (pd.DataFrame): The initial DataFrame. - tracking_column (str): The tracking column name. - evaluation_dataframe (pd.DataFrame or None): Stores interpolation method evaluation results. - method_success_dataframe (pd.DataFrame or None): Records success or failure of each interpolation method for each column.

Example Usage:

import pandas as pd
# Example DataFrame
data = {
    'date': pd.date_range(start='1/1/2020', periods=5),
    'value': [1, 2, np.nan, 4, 5]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
tw = TimeWeaver(df, 'date')
tw.evaluate()

Note

This class is designed to work with pandas DataFrames and requires the pandas library.

evaluate(missing_rate=0.1, random: bool = True, prints: bool = True, logging: bool = False)

Evaluates various interpolation methods on the DataFrame, under specified conditions.

Parameters

  • missing_rate (float) – Proportion of values to be randomly removed from each column for interpolation testing.

  • random (bool) – Determines if missing values are randomly selected or evenly spaced.

  • prints (bool) – Controls printout of log messages during the evaluation process.

  • logging (bool) – Enables logging of warning messages for interpolation methods that result in errors or NaNs.

Example Usage:

tw.evaluate(missing_rate=0.2, random=True, prints=True, logging=True)
fill_edge_nans(df: DataFrame)

Applies forward and backward filling to address NaN values at the start and end of each DataFrame column.

This method modifies the input DataFrame in place by filling NaN values at the edges of each column. It uses forward fill (ffill) to fill NaNs at the beginning of a column and backward fill (bfill) to fill NaNs at the end.

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing potential edge NaN values to be filled.

Returns

The modified DataFrame with edge NaN values filled.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Example Usage:

df = pd.DataFrame({
    'A': [np.nan, 2, 3, np.nan],
    'B': [1, np.nan, 3, 4]
})
filled_df = tw.fill_edge_nans(df)
print(filled_df)

Note: The method modifies the DataFrame in place but also returns the DataFrame for chaining operations or assignment.

get_best(optimized_selection: bool = True)

Identifies the best interpolation method(s) for each column based on the evaluation results.

Parameters

optimized_selection (bool) – Selects methods based on performance and frequency of being best if True. Otherwise, selects the method(s) with the lowest error.

Returns

Mapping each column to the best interpolation method(s) or a list of (column, method) tuples.

Return type

dict or list

Example Usage:

best_methods = tw.get_best(optimized_selection=True)
print(best_methods)
get_evaluation_dataframe(style: bool = True)

Retrieves the evaluation DataFrame with optional styling to highlight the lowest values.

Parameters

style (bool) – Applies styling if set to True.

Returns

Evaluation DataFrame, optionally styled.

Return type

pd.DataFrame or Styler

Example Usage:

eval_df = tw.get_evaluation_dataframe(style=True)
get_method_success_dataframe(style: bool = True)

Retrieves the method success DataFrame with optional styling to highlight False values.

Parameters

style (bool) – Applies styling if set to True.

Returns

Method success DataFrame, optionally styled.

Return type

pd.DataFrame or Styler

Example Usage:

success_df = tw.get_method_success_dataframe(style=True)
get_rate_analysis(start_rate: float = 0.1, end_rate: float = 0.5, step: float = 0.01, prints: bool = False)

Analyzes interpolation method performance across a range of missing data rates.

Parameters

  • start_rate (float) – The starting missing rate for evaluation.

  • end_rate (float) – The ending missing rate for evaluation.

  • step (float) – The step size between evaluated missing rates.

  • prints (bool) – If True, prints log messages during the analysis.

Example Usage:

tw.get_rate_analysis(start_rate=0.1, end_rate=0.5, step=0.05, prints=True)
get_summary(full_summary: bool = False)

Creates a summary of various statistics for each column in the DataFrame, including counts of numeric and non-numeric cells, NaNs, and zeros. Optionally includes detailed statistics like unique values count, most frequent value, minimum, maximum, mean, and median.

Parameters

full_summary (bool) – Includes detailed statistics if True. Default is False.

Returns

A DataFrame summarizing the statistics for each column.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Example Usage:

summary_df = tw.get_summary(full_summary=True)
print(summary_df)

Note: The function calculates basic counts by default. Set full_summary=True for an extended set of statistics, applicable primarily to numeric columns.

get_summary_characters(set_regex_pattern=None)

Generates a summary DataFrame containing various statistics for each column in the original DataFrame.

Parameters

full_summary (bool) – If True, includes additional statistics such as unique values count, most frequent value, and more.

Returns

A DataFrame containing summary statistics for each column.

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Example Usage:

summary_df = tw.get_summary(full_summary=True)
print(summary_df)
highlight_false(s)

Highlights False values in a Series, used primarily for visualizing method success or failure.

Parameters

s (pd.Series) – Series of boolean values indicating success (True) or failure (False).

Returns

List of styles to be applied for highlighting False values.

Return type

list

Example Usage:

styled_df = method_success_df.style.apply(tw.highlight_false, axis=1)
highlight_lowest(s)

Highlights the lowest non-negative value in a Series for visualization.

Parameters

s (pd.Series) – Series of values to be highlighted.

Returns

List of styles to be applied for highlighting.

Return type

list

Example Usage:

styled_df = df.style.apply(tw.highlight_lowest, axis=1)
log(message, overwrite=True)

Prints a formatted log message to the console. Can overwrite the current line or print on a new line.

Parameters

  • message (str) – The message to be logged.

  • overwrite (bool) – If True, the message overwrites the current line in the console. If False, the message is printed on a new line.

preprocess()

Placeholder method for preprocessing the DataFrame. This method should be implemented to include specific preprocessing steps as needed.

Usage Example

import pandas as pd
from your_module_name import TimeWeaver  # Replace with your actual module name

# Sample DataFrame
data = {'time': pd.date_range(start='2021-01-01', periods=5, freq='D'),
        'value': [1, 2, np.nan, 4, 5]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Initialize TimeWeaver
tw = TimeWeaver(df, 'time')

# Get summary characters
print(tw.get_summary_characters())

# Evaluate interpolation methods
tw.evaluate()
